授業の概要・背景:
COURSE DESCRIPTIONS:
This course is composed of three sections. First, we will focus on the evolution and development of IOs in the historical context. Second, we will learn why and how states create and use IOs and how IOs may influence state behaviors. We will do so by surveying and examining various theoretical arguments on the roles of IOs in global governance. Third, we will explore and discuss the role of IOs in particular issue areas. The course is conducted in lecture format supplemented with class discussion.

LUNA:
We will be using LUNA for this course. I will post all course materials, announcements, and grades on this system. You will also post your final essay on LUNA. Please note that it is your responsibility to check for course updates on LUNA on a regular basis.

All materials related to the course (including lecture slides) are copyrighted. You are prohibited to upload, distribute, or publish through any SNS and websites.

INSTRUCTOR CONTACT:
Please feel free to contact me via email (hlt39472@kwansei.ac.jp) any time you think discussion on an individual basis would be helpful. It is important to me that this course enriches your educational experience.

ANTHER REQUIREMENTS:
Classroom Etiquette: Please recognize that our classroom includes people with various life experiences, divergent perspectives, and different levels of English proficiency.

Academic Honesty: Students are expected to adhere to Honor Code policies on all assignments and exams. Also, students are strongly urged to familiarize themselves with the definition of plagiarism and avoid it.

Grade Appeals: If you think a grade I assigned you is incorrect, you can request me to consider re-grading. All grade appeals, however, must be made in writing. You should write a brief memo explaining your concerns and submit this memo to me along with the graded assignment. I will review your concerns and I may re-grade if necessary.

DISCLAIMER:
I reserve the right to modify the syllabus and assignments throughout the semester. Modifications will be well communicated through LUNA and in class.

Grades will be determined in the manner described below. The grading scale for this course is as follows: 100-90 S, 89-85 A+, 84-80 A, 79-75 B+, 74-70 B, 69-65 C+, 64-60 C, 59-0 F

(1) Attendance and Participation in Discussion (50%)
This includes both attendance and the quality of your participation in class discussion. Thus, regular attendance is expected and will not raise your participation grade. If you do not attend, however, your participation grade will be reduced. You are expected to have completed the assigned readings before class and to be able to contribute to the class discussion. If no one volunteers, then I will randomly call on people. You are also expected to treat other students with civility and respect.

(2) Final Essay (50%)
Each student must turn in an analytical essay of no more than 8 pages (typed and double spaced, using a 11 size font with 2cm margins), in response to questions based on the readings and additional topics covered in each session of the class. The essay questions will be notified a few weeks before the Session 14. Your essay should not merely summarize the assigned readings. Rather, you need to critically evaluate the readings and make our own arguments. You are required to turn in your essay through LUNA.
